page.title: 04More Buildings in Calbourne
page.content: {WINKLE STREET }(meaning a cul-de-sac) is composed of a row of well preserved 17th century cottages, mostly of stone and many still thatched. Originally built for Westover tenants they were afterwards owned by the Barrington Simeons when Winkle Street became Barrington Row, but the old name is generally more often used. They are now mainly privately owned and well modernised. The 18th century stone built{ {NEWBARN}to the east of the village is occupied by the Spence family as a working farm. Though modernised it still retains original features such as doorways and windows. The old{SCHOOL and SCHOOLHOUSE} was built in the 19th century as a church school. Closed when the numbers fell in the 1950s it is now two homes.
